pt.traditional.title: Por Que as Solu√ß√µes Tradicionais N√£o Funcionam
pt.traditional.intro: Voc√™ provavelmente j√° considerou (ou tentou) algumas destas op√ß√µes. Entenda por que elas falham ‚Äî e o que funciona no lugar.
pt.traditional.row1.fail: 12-18 meses de ramp. 50% taxa de falha. Custo de R$1M+/ano all-in. Se n√£o funcionar, voc√™ perdeu 18 meses e muito dinheiro.
pt.traditional.row1.solution: Instalar a arquitetura primeiro. Contratar VP quando a m√°quina estiver funcionando e voc√™ souber exatamente o perfil certo.
pt.traditional.row2.fail: R$500k-1.5M por PowerPoints bonitos. Zero execu√ß√£o. Consultores juniores fazendo benchmarks gen√©ricos. Voc√™ fica com o deck, n√£o com resultado.
pt.traditional.row2.solution: Execu√ß√£o hands-on, 2 dias/semana na opera√ß√£o. Metas semanais, n√£o relat√≥rios mensais. Pele no jogo.
pt.traditional.row3.fail: 1 hora por m√™s n√£o muda cad√™ncia operacional. GPs n√£o t√™m tempo para execu√ß√£o. Conselho estrat√©gico n√£o vira pipeline.
pt.traditional.row3.solution: Rigor de board + execu√ß√£o di√°ria. Algu√©m que fala a l√≠ngua do board mas est√° na trincheira.
pt.traditional.row4.fail: Context switching constante. Produto sempre ganha de vendas na prioriza√ß√£o. CEO vira gargalo. Burnout garantido.
pt.traditional.row4.solution: Co-ownership de revenue com CEO. Founder livre para focar em produto e estrat√©gia. Accountability compartilhada.
pt.traditional.row5.fail: Se o processo est√° quebrado, mais reps = mais caos. Voc√™ escala o problema, n√£o a solu√ß√£o. CAC explode.
pt.traditional.row5.solution: Consertar o processo primeiro. Depois escalar. Na ordem certa, cada rep novo √© multiplicador, n√£o custo.

pt.faq.title: Perguntas Frequentes
pt.faq.subtitle: Tudo o que voc√™ precisa saber sobre o modelo de Fractional CRO
pt.faq.a1: Um Fractional CRO (Chief Revenue Officer Fracion√°rio) √© um executivo s√™nior de receita que trabalha parcialmente para sua empresa, tipicamente 2-3 dias por semana.
pt.faq.a1b: Diferente de consultores que entregam relat√≥rios, o Fractional CRO executa: participa de forecast, treina vendedores, estrutura processos e tem accountability por resultados. Ideal para empresas B2B tech entre R$5M-50M de receita que precisam de lideran√ßa s√™nior mas n√£o justificam um executivo full-time.
pt.faq.q2: Quanto custa um Fractional CRO no Brasil?
pt.faq.a2: Um Fractional CRO no Brasil tipicamente custa entre R$25.000 e R$60.000 por m√™s, dependendo da senioridade e do tempo dedicado. Faixas de mercado:
pt.faq.a2b: Compare com um CRO full-time que custaria R$80.000-150.000 mensais em sal√°rio, benef√≠cios e equity. O modelo fracion√°rio oferece 70-80% do impacto por 30-40% do custo.
pt.faq.q3: Quando devo contratar um Fractional CRO?
pt.faq.a3: Sua empresa deve considerar um Fractional CRO quando:
pt.faq.a3.item1: Receita entre R$5M-50M e crescimento travou h√° 6+ meses
pt.faq.a3.item2: CEO est√° gastando mais de 40% do tempo em vendas
pt.faq.a3.item3: N√£o tem or√ßamento para VP Sales full-time
pt.faq.a3.item4: Pipeline tem cobertura menor que 2x da meta
pt.faq.a3.item6: Forecast erra mais de 25% do previsto
pt.faq.a3.item7: Churn de vendedores acima de 30% ao ano
pt.faq.a3b: Empresas S√©rie A/B s√£o o sweet spot para este modelo.
pt.faq.q4: Qual a diferen√ßa entre Fractional CRO e consultoria?
pt.faq.a4: Consultoria entrega diagn√≥sticos, frameworks e recomenda√ß√µes (PowerPoints). O Fractional CRO executa: participa de reuni√µes de forecast, treina reps, estrutura processos, cobra resultados.
pt.faq.a4b: Consultores cobram por projeto sem accountability. Fractional CRO tem metas e frequentemente inclui success fee atrelado a resultados.
pt.faq.a4c: Consultoria Big4 pode custar R$300.000-500.000 por projeto de 3 meses sem execu√ß√£o. Fractional CRO custa R$25.000-60.000/m√™s com execu√ß√£o cont√≠nua.
pt.faq.q5: Como funciona o modelo na pr√°tica?
pt.faq.a5.item4: Time: Treinamento e coaching do time comercial
pt.faq.a5b: O engajamento come√ßa com diagn√≥stico de 30 dias, seguido de implementa√ß√£o de quick wins e constru√ß√£o de arquitetura de GTM sustent√°vel. Contratos t√≠picos s√£o de 6-12 meses.
pt.faq.q6: Fractional CRO ou VP de Vendas full-time?
pt.faq.a6.item1: A empresa ainda n√£o sabe exatamente que perfil de VP precisa
pt.faq.a6.item2: N√£o tem or√ßamento para executivo full-time (R$80-150k/m√™s)
pt.faq.a6.item3: Precisa de resultados r√°pidos (VP leva 12-18 meses para performar)
pt.faq.a6.item4: Quer estruturar processos antes de trazer lideran√ßa permanente
pt.faq.a6b: VP full-time √© melhor quando: a empresa tem processos maduros, pode pagar compensa√ß√£o competitiva com equity, e precisa de dedica√ß√£o integral.
pt.faq.a6c: Muitas empresas usam Fractional CRO para construir a base e depois contratar VP quando a m√°quina est√° funcionando.
pt.faq.a7: Carlos Andr√© √© o fundador da Alavanka e atua como Fractional CRO para empresas B2B tech brasileiras. Seu track record inclui:
pt.faq.a7.item1: Oracle Brasil: Presidente ‚Äî escalou de $48M para $240M em 5 anos
pt.faq.a7.item2: AT&T LATAM: CEO ‚Äî cresceu de $3M para $47M em 2 anos
pt.faq.a7b: Tamb√©m √© Mentor Endeavor, professor no INSPER e conselheiro certificado IBGC. Atende no m√°ximo 3 empresas simultaneamente.
pt.faq.a8.item1: Dia 30: Avalia√ß√£o se h√° fit cultural e operacional
pt.faq.a8.item2: Dia 90: Avalia√ß√£o se as m√©tricas acordadas est√£o evoluindo
pt.faq.a8b: Se n√£o estiver funcionando em qualquer checkpoint, encerramos sem drama. Voc√™ n√£o fica preso a um contrato longo se os resultados n√£o aparecerem.
pt.faq.a8c: Al√©m disso, parte da compensa√ß√£o √© success fee ‚Äî s√≥ ganhamos mais se voc√™ crescer. Isso garante alinhamento total de interesses.

en.problem.card1.item5: Runway shrinking while debating \"more reps or new strategy?\"
en.problem.card1.item6: Competition advancing with clearly inferior product
en.problem.card2.item1: Company in the \"zombie zone\" ‚Äî not dying, but not growing
en.problem.card2.item2: CEO in burnout, 60% of time fighting sales fires
en.problem.card2.item4: Follow-on at risk or requiring down-round
en.problem.card2.item5: 4-6h/month of GP in crisis mode per company
en.problem.card2.item6: Exit multiple compressing while market waits
en.consequences.title: The Cost of Inaction
en.consequences.subtitle: Every month of stagnation has a compounding price
en.consequences.card1.title: Trapped Capital
en.consequences.card1.text: Investment locked in underperforming asset. Every month without growth is capital that could be generating returns elsewhere.
en.consequences.card2.title: Valuation Compressing
en.consequences.card2.text: SaaS multiples depend on growth. Stagnation today means down-round tomorrow ‚Äî or forced exit at liquidation price.
en.consequences.card3.title: Talent Leaving
en.consequences.card3.text: The best notice first. Top performers don't stay at stagnant companies. Who stays are those without options.
en.consequences.card4.title: Window Closing
en.consequences.card4.text: Markets don't wait. While you debate strategy, competitors are executing and capturing your prospects.
en.consequences.card5.title: Founder Burnout
en.consequences.card5.text: CEO spending 60% of time on sales isn't building product, culture or strategy. It's unsustainable.
en.consequences.card6.title: Credibility Eroding
en.consequences.card6.text: Every missed target, every delayed milestone. The board loses confidence. LPs question. The cycle feeds itself.
en.consequences.urgency.title: The math is cruel
en.consequences.urgency.text: A $2M ARR company with 0% growth is worth a fraction of one with 30%. Every stagnant quarter costs millions in equity value.
en.ideal.title: What Should Be Happening
en.ideal.subtitle: If GTM was working, you'd see this:
en.ideal.sales.title: In Sales Operations
en.ideal.sales.item1: Pipeline with 3x+ coverage of quota, always
en.ideal.sales.item2: Clear process: every rep knows exactly what to do at each stage
en.ideal.sales.item5: Reliable forecast ‚Äî no surprises at quarter end
en.ideal.sales.item6: New reps productive in 90 days, not 6 months
en.ideal.financial.title: In Financial Metrics
en.ideal.financial.item1: NRR above 110% ‚Äî expansion paying for growth
en.ideal.financial.item4: Churn under control with documented reasons
en.ideal.financial.item6: Metrics that impress in the next round
en.ideal.founder.title: In the Founder's Day-to-Day
en.ideal.founder.item1: CEO focused on product, strategy and culture
en.ideal.founder.item2: Board meetings are updates, not interrogations
en.ideal.founder.item3: Confidence to delegate revenue to someone who understands
en.ideal.founder.item5: Energy to think about next step, not today's fire
en.ideal.investor.title: For the Investor
en.ideal.investor.item2: Metrics that support follow-on or exit
en.ideal.investor.item3: Fewer GP hours in crisis mode
en.ideal.investor.item4: Replicable playbook for other portfolio companies
en.ideal.transform.title: This isn't fantasy
en.ideal.transform.text: It's what happens when you have GTM architecture installed and disciplined execution against the right metrics.
en.traditional.title: Why Traditional Solutions Don't Work
en.traditional.intro: You've probably considered (or tried) some of these options. Understand why they fail ‚Äî and what works instead.
en.traditional.row1.fail: 12-18 months ramp. 50% failure rate. Cost of $200K+/year all-in. If it doesn't work, you lost 18 months and a lot of money.
en.traditional.row1.solution: Install the architecture first. Hire VP when the machine is running and you know exactly the right profile.
en.traditional.row2.fail: $100k-300k for pretty PowerPoints. Zero execution. Junior consultants doing generic benchmarks. You keep the deck, not results.
en.traditional.row2.solution: Hands-on execution, 2 days/week in operations. Weekly targets, not monthly reports. Skin in the game.
en.traditional.row3.fail: 1 hour per month doesn't change operational cadence. GPs don't have time for execution. Strategic advice doesn't become pipeline.
en.traditional.row3.solution: Board rigor + daily execution. Someone who speaks board language but is in the trenches.
en.traditional.row4.fail: Constant context switching. Product always wins over sales in prioritization. CEO becomes bottleneck. Guaranteed burnout.
en.traditional.row4.solution: Revenue co-ownership with CEO. Founder free to focus on product and strategy. Shared accountability.
en.traditional.row5.fail: If the process is broken, more reps = more chaos. You scale the problem, not the solution. CAC explodes.
en.traditional.row5.solution: Fix the process first. Then scale. In the right order, every new rep is a multiplier, not a cost.
en.why.track.item1: Oracle Brazil: $48M ‚Üí $240M in 5 years as President
en.why.track.item2: AT&T LATAM: $3M ‚Üí $47M in 2 years as CEO

en.why.track.item4: LoySci: 9 years as Co-Founder and CEO
en.why.diff.item1: Operator, not consultant ‚Äî I've sat in the chair you're sitting in
en.why.diff.item2: Execution > Opinion ‚Äî metrics, not narratives. Results, not reports
en.why.diff.item3: Skin in the game ‚Äî success fee tied to real results
en.why.diff.item5: Kill-switch ‚Äî didn't work in 30 days? We end it without drama

en.process.deliverables.title: What Gets Installed in Your Operation
en.model.title: Commercial Model
en.model.subtitle: Structure aligned to results ‚Äî not hours
en.model.retainer.title: Monthly Retainer
en.model.retainer.text: 2 days/week dedication + 1 surge day/month. Consistent presence in operations, not sporadic visits.
en.model.success.title: Success Fee
en.model.success.text: Percentage on ARR growth above baseline. We only earn more if you grow more. Real skin in the game.
en.model.equity.title: Equity (Optional)
en.model.equity.text: Performance warrants that only vest if we hit specific NRR and CAC payback metrics.
en.model.principles.title: Model Principles
en.model.principle1: Kill-switch on Day 30 and Day 90 ‚Äî didn't work, we end it
en.model.principle3: Metrics agreed before starting ‚Äî no ambiguity
en.model.principle4: Success fee with cap ‚Äî alignment, not extraction
en.model.principle5: Clawback if exceptional churn ‚Äî shared responsibility
en.model.principle6: Structured handover ‚Äî you keep the installed capacity
en.fit.title: This Service Isn't For Everyone
en.fit.subtitle: We're very specific about who we work with. If you don't fit the profile, we'll tell you ‚Äî and probably refer you to someone more suitable.
en.fit.positive.title: We Work With Companies That...
en.fit.positive.item1: Have annual revenue of at least $2M
en.fit.positive.item2: Have raised Series B or later
en.fit.positive.item3: Have proven market traction (customers paying, renewing)
en.fit.positive.item4: Validated product ‚Äî the problem is GTM, not product-market fit
en.fit.positive.item5: Stagnated in growth for 6+ months despite effort
en.fit.positive.item6: Coachable CEO and board aligned with intervention
en.fit.negative.title: We Don't Work With Companies That...
en.fit.negative.item3: Runway less than 9 months (not enough time)
en.fit.negative.item5: Don't have customer success team (broken retention kills growth)
en.fit.negative.item6: Burn greater than 2x revenue without clear path to efficiency
en.cross.title: Expanding into Latin America?
en.cross.text: Alavanka.com offers Market Entry Partnership ‚Äî a Build-Operate-Transfer model for B2B Tech companies looking to expand into LATAM with controlled risk. Same team, same methodology, different focus.
en.faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
en.faq.subtitle: Everything you need to know about the Fractional CRO model
en.faq.a1: A Fractional CRO (Fractional Chief Revenue Officer) is a senior revenue executive who works part-time for your company, typically 2-3 days per week.
en.faq.a1b: Unlike consultants who deliver reports, the Fractional CRO executes: participates in forecasts, trains salespeople, structures processes, and has accountability for results. Ideal for B2B tech companies with $1M-10M revenue that need senior leadership but can't justify a full-time executive.
en.faq.q2: How much does a Fractional CRO cost in Brazil?
en.faq.a2: A Fractional CRO in Brazil typically costs between $5,000 and $12,000 per month, depending on seniority and time commitment. Market ranges:
en.faq.a2b: Compare with a full-time CRO costing $16,000-30,000 monthly in salary, benefits, and equity. The fractional model delivers 70-80% of the impact at 30-40% of the cost.
en.faq.q3: When should I hire a Fractional CRO?
en.faq.a3: Your company should consider a Fractional CRO when:
en.faq.a3.item1: Revenue between $1M-10M and growth has stalled for 6+ months
en.faq.a3.item2: CEO is spending more than 40% of time on sales
en.faq.a3.item3: No budget for a full-time VP Sales
en.faq.a3.item4: Pipeline coverage is less than 2x target
en.faq.a3.item7: Sales rep turnover above 30% per year
en.faq.a3b: Series A/B companies are the sweet spot for this model.
en.faq.q4: What's the difference between Fractional CRO and consulting?
en.faq.a4: Consulting delivers diagnoses, frameworks, and recommendations (PowerPoints). The Fractional CRO executes: participates in forecast meetings, trains reps, structures processes, drives accountability.
en.faq.a4b: Consultants charge per project without accountability. Fractional CRO has targets and often includes success fees tied to results.
en.faq.a4c: Big4 consulting can cost $60,000-100,000 for a 3-month project without execution. Fractional CRO costs $5,000-12,000/month with continuous execution.
en.faq.q5: How does the model work in practice?
en.faq.a5.item4: Team: Training and coaching of commercial team
en.faq.a5b: Engagement starts with a 30-day diagnosis, followed by quick wins implementation and building sustainable GTM architecture. Typical contracts are 6-12 months.
en.faq.q6: Fractional CRO or full-time VP of Sales?
en.faq.a6.item1: The company doesn't know exactly what VP profile it needs
en.faq.a6.item3: Needs quick results (VP takes 12-18 months to perform)
en.faq.a6.item4: Wants to structure processes before bringing permanent leadership
en.faq.a6b: Full-time VP is better when: the company has mature processes, can pay competitive compensation with equity, and needs full-time dedication.
en.faq.a6c: Many companies use Fractional CRO to build the foundation and then hire a VP when the machine is running.
en.faq.q7: Who is Carlos Andr√© from Alavanka?
en.faq.a7: Carlos Andr√© is the founder of Alavanka and works as a Fractional CRO for Brazilian B2B tech companies. His track record includes:
en.faq.a7.item1: Oracle Brazil: President ‚Äî scaled from $48M to $240M in 5 years
en.faq.a7.item2: AT&T LATAM: CEO ‚Äî grew from $3M to $47M in 2 years
en.faq.a7b: Also an Endeavor Mentor, INSPER professor, and IBGC-certified board member. Works with maximum 3 companies simultaneously.
en.faq.a8.item1: Day 30: Assessment of cultural and operational fit
en.faq.a8.item2: Day 90: Assessment of whether agreed metrics are improving
en.faq.a8b: If it's not working at any checkpoint, we end it without drama. You're not stuck in a long contract if results don't materialize.
en.faq.a8c: Additionally, part of compensation is success fee ‚Äî we only earn more if you grow. This ensures total alignment of interests.
